text:
but it's been a busy
year trying to get the Robotics Center going. And how many of you were around
for the launch in November?

Did you know about it? Did you see it participate? Not a lot of you. So I'm going to talk a
little bit about that.

And I think the word
of the talk is impact. This is the way I
think about the world.

Willow Garage was
a strange company.
It was a think tank.
It had a research lab component. It wasn't just research. It had a commercial component.

It was technically a for-profit,
but it didn't make a profit.

And we said as a mantra,
we want impact first, return on capital second.

That was the goal. And I think we achieved
the impact part. And I'm sure that
we did not achieve

from the founder and
funders point of view, the return on capital part. But if you look at the total
amount of value created

from what Willow Garage started
in ROS and the companies that have used ROS to raise money,
I think there's obviously

a huge economic impact. So I'll come back
to Willow Garage.

Let me tell you a little bit
about the Robotics Center. And as Mark
mentioned, my journey,

I was here as a
student back in-- and I wasn't a
robotics student here. I was in digital
libraries project.
My classmate was Larry Page. I like to joke that I finished. He did OK.

I told him that joke, he
said, I'm in a dead end job.

But it was a very
interesting time and it was a time
of collaboration. And I got to experience
collaboration

among multiple faculty. So that actually did
lead to very big impact. And the spinout from
here Google, obviously

you all know about was
started shortly thereafter. So I came back to Stanford.

I got into robotics
at Willow Garage days and I came back to
Stanford recently because while it's great to
work on a startup company

and try to put robots in
the world, what you find is you spend your time
selling the robots.

Once you get it
built, you're going to spend your time selling
it, developing the market. And a lot of the
problems you address

are not robotics problems. And I wanted to get back to
the cutting edge of robotics,

which is where you all are. So you should appreciate that. The other thing I'll say
looking back on my time

as a student is that, so many of
the people that I was classmates

with did very, very, very well. I mean, it turned out to
be, like Mehran Sahami

was a teammate of mine
on a robotics class. He's the chairman of the
CS department here now.

And you don't know
who it's going to be.
So look around. Keep in touch with these people. There's a big valuable part. I didn't learn that lesson.

That's a GSB lesson that
I'll just give you for free. Keep in touch with
your colleagues.

The point of the
Stanford Robotics Center is to empower robotics
research collaboration.

work together in order to
advance robotics to help people in the planet. So that's quick
statement, bring together

cross-disciplinary
researchers from industry and Stanford for transformative
impact on people and the planet.

And that's the big idea. So the idea is that
robotics is complicated.

It's very hard. If any of you can do
a whole robot from CAD design all the way
through software,

I'll challenge you to then
do human robot interaction and then do a business
model on top of that. If you can do all of that
yourself, you're amazing.

I think I know of
one person who might be able to do that
in all my-- and I've met a lot of really
smart people.

It's a stack. And it takes a team
to do robotics, which is what makes it fun. There's 35 faculty
now across Stanford

who are robotics faculty
affiliated with the center. So it is a very
cross-disciplinary activity.

The new faculty members, five
of them since the launch. Because the thing
about the launch

is that you get a lot of
recognition and people say, oh, look at this.

So we think about robotics,
and I mentioned the big stack.

You have the knowledge. You have the core knowledge
of robotics and know how. How do we actually make robots?

How do we do sensing? How do we do perception,
reasoning, planning? All those traditional
robotics topics

that you'll read about in
the Handbook of Robotics or whatever textbook you have,
or maybe not textbooks anymore,

you'll learn about in classes. Design is critical
on top of that. Once you know how
to make robots work,

you've got to design
them because they're going to go out in the
world and in the future,

they're mostly going
to be around people. If you look at the
history of robotics, I mean, robotics has
been around for 60 years.

We had robots in the '60s
and '70s that were hydraulic.

They're not even
electronic robots. And were pretty much
all behind safety cages.

I mean, a few exceptions,
research lab robots, but pretty much any
robot that was deployed was around safety cages.

Why? Because we didn't know
how to make them safe. We just punt it on safety. Put it behind a safety cage.

We need them to weld. We need them to move really
fast and have a lot of inertia.

And if anybody gets
near them, they're going to get their
head cracked open. So stay away. We got better.

The second phase of robotics
I would say we're in now is robots that are around us.

You talk about cobots
in manufacturing. Talk about arms. Talk about self-driving cars
or robots that are around us.

And the rules of the game
are don't hit people. In fact, don't touch
people if you can avoid it.

If you're stopped, it's
OK, they can touch you. But otherwise,
don't touch people. Don't hit people.

Going forward, we have to be
able to think about solving the next level of problems.

We need to be able to
interact with people and ideally touch them gently
enough that you can help them

get out of bed, help
them get to the toilet, help them with aging tasks. We're doing surgery with robots.

We have to be really
cognizant about safety. We're not doing,
as far as I know, very much autonomous surgery
in the world right now.

We're doing surgery
under surgeon's control, and the robot is
essentially a tool, which

is another interesting piece. Because when you talk about what
is a robot going to do for you,

is the robot just going
to weld cars all day? I mean, they used
to, that was a task.

But what do we
need robots to do? And I know, we think about AI.

Are we going to have the robot
just be an intelligent robot? We're going to embody
it in a humanoid, and it's going to
go off and do what?

Help us do stuff. But is that the only use? And let me just give you a
counter example real quick

that came up at Willow Garage.  There's a project was
called Robots for Humanity.

And basically, we had
this PR2 robot, which I'll talk about in a minute. Two-armed robot, mobile-base.

We gave away 10 of them. And I'll talk about
how that came to be. But I got this email
one day and it said,

I saw your robot on CNN. And I'm mute and
I'm quadriplegic.

And that robot could be my
external body, can I try it? This is not about autonomy.

This is not about AI. This is about somebody who wants
to basically be able to move, but they can't physically move.

And all they can do
is move their head. And the guy's name, he
lives in here in Palo Alto. His name is Henry Evans.
And Henry came down. We did some evaluations.

He was so excited. He went away and spent time with
his head drawing a PowerPoint presentation of how
he wanted the UI to be

and sent that back to us. And Willow Garage was a strange
place that we could do this.

We just hired a
student at Georgia Tech to build that interface for him. And eventually Henry
sat next to the robot.

He had the robot
here, PR2 and Henry was sitting here
with his computer. And he starts moving
the robot, not

picking up the things on the
table that we had to manipulate. But we thought he was
going to do manipulation. He turned the robot on himself,
and he started bringing the hand

toward his head. Now we're a little bit nervous. We had a human subjects
people in the room.

They were very nervous. We had a big red button. Henry put the robot's hand
right in front of his nose

and then scratched his itch. And that was the
first time in 10 years he'd scratch his own itch. He was so happy.

And we're like, nobody
else in that room had thought about that
as a task for a robot.

The next thing we want
to do is shave himself. We didn't give him
a straight razor. We gave him a electric razor
and he moved it to here.

And then he did this,
and he shaved himself. And he actually shaved a
bunch of different places.

He pushed really hard and made
himself bleed a little bit. And he was so happy and
the human subjects people

were terrified. No blood. But the point is when
we think about robotics

and we think about
robotic technology, what it can do for the world, it's
not always what we imagine.

And it's about us
being in control and being able to do
things for ourselves. So robots help me, I mean,
if I come home every day

and my house is clean
because a robot picked up all the socks and laundry and
made it neat, wonderful, great.

I don't actually want to be
involved in that process. Have that happen automatically. But if I'm going to take a
trip to the south of France

and you say, hey, I have
an autonomous humanoid who can take the trip for you, I'm
like, wait, wait, wait, wait, I want to go.

That's my trip. So back to the SRC. So Stanford Robotics Center
is focused on five areas.

And actually I should say
six because count the middle. We're building a core of
robotics research and technology

among the Stanford community,
across those 35 faculty. We're building that
core of technology

because we need
to work together. We have to share technology
in order to work together.

The reason that we created
ROS at Willow Garage was because before
that, everybody was

rolling their own everything. And so when you went
to a conference, you showed each other videos.

Hey, watch it. And you guys know what goes
on with robotics videos. That was the one time it worked.

And then you have outtakes. But what we want to have is
some ability to share results,

to be able to have
other people repeat. That's why we built
the PR2 and ROS, was so that people could
work across universities

on a common platform. A common platform takes
work, but the benefits

are that you can
inherit hopefully a lot more than you give back. But you got to put
some energy into it.

The other areas around that
core, a future of work, so manufacturing and logistics.

Field robotics, of
which there's a lot of different areas
medical robotics, surgery,

and rehabilitation and others,
education and culture, and last

but not least, domestic robots. Now I have a
love/hate relationship with domestic robots.

The idea of domestic robots. Because on the one hand,
of course, everybody wants a robot to-- we actually
did a survey at Willow Garage.

What do you want
from your robot? I want to do my laundry. Great. By the way, you already have
two machines to do that.

I want to do my dishes. You already have
one machine, but OK. And I want to do
my homework, which
is just inherently a bad idea. And anyway, now we have ChatGPT. So you get that.

But domestic robots, if
you think about it as, there are people
like Henry who live at home who need help, either
to help himself or need

other people to care for them. And we have a huge problem in
this world of demographic shift,

where there's going to
be a lot of people who need help living in the home. It actually becomes a
really interesting area.

Our idea is to have
flagship projects around these and their
spaces in the Robotics

Center for each of
these areas where we can have projects to focus.

So we had this big launch. And let me just show
you a quick video of the launch of the center.
Because I have to click.

[VIDEO PLAYBACK] - The Robotics Center,
the idea is really about how can we bring an
environment for collaboration.

Our idea is really bringing
multidisciplinary research to work together with
industry to create

innovations that will make
an impact on our planet
and on people.

We are spanning field robotics. We are looking at
the future of work

in domestic robotics, education,
and culture, art, and also

a lot of effort in medical
robotics and wellness.

And we are going to try attempt
to make research more focused

on the real-world applications. And that cannot be done
without working together with

the industry on those
applications and those challenges. [END PLAYBACK]

So obviously, a successful--
oops, a successful launch.

And now what? That's the way I'm
thinking about it.

We've got a lot of attention. We've got a lot of people
calling saying, oh, can I have a tour? Actually, we're overwhelmed
with that right now.

But in the course of this
launch for the last summer, we put together 50 demos.

We were shooting for 30
to 40, so we overachieved. If you look at that
QR code, there's

a web page that links
basically to all 50 demos if you want to go
explore what they were, if you didn't get to see them.

It talks about all
the different areas. And it's just an example
of a lot of diversity.

So there was this
robot, which by the way has no motor, no
compute, no sensors.

Why is it a robot? But it is a tiny robot
from mechanical engineering

from Renee Zhao's Lab
that is controlled by an external magnetic
field and external sensors

and can swim in
your bloodstream. Why do you want a little robot
swimming in your bloodstream? I know there was a movie
like this in the '60s, but I

don't remember. But the answer is if
it hits a blood clot,

it'll break up the blood clot. So if you're having
a stroke, this is actually one of the
best ways potentially to stop the stroke from
happening, to restore

blood flow to your brain. You can put medicine inside
of one of these tiny robots and drive it exactly
to the location

you want it to go, and then
inject the medicine using a different magnetic field. So a lot of really
interesting ideas.

How do we control it? We have an external robot
arm with a magnet spinning

next to your body that's
moving it inside of your body. So this is a very
different robotics.

This was a Helmholtz coil
that we used to test that. And if you come down to
the lab or to the center

sometime you can try
a joystick and try to drive one of those
robots through the hoops. I always say that
there's little hoops

in the middle of that tank,
and that was my suggestion. Small contributions.

But these are some new ways to
think about robots is something that we saw. We had over 1,000 visitors over
the two weekends to the center

in November. And just a lot of different
demos and people coming through

and interest. So as I say, after the
launch symposium, what next?

We want to be a bridge
between research and real-world applications.

That's the goal. That if you're just doing pure
research in a small area or even

in a large area, if you can
do research in your lab, you should do research in
your lab, that existed. That's not a problem
that needs to be solved.

But we want to be able
to do bigger problems, to address bigger problems
with social impact that require

multiple labs to work together. And the center provides a
space and some resources to be able to do that.

We're also, of course,
care about education. So we're sponsoring this
seminar for example. And we're sponsoring
eventually, fleets of robots

that may be used in classes. And we've got an
outreach mission

to talk to people from
outside the university about how do robots work?

How those robotics can impact
their lives and things. So we talk about that. In the end of the
day, the center

is a way to basically
build a community here at Stanford of robotics people. And hopefully all of you who
can work together and provide

a place for that. So how do we do that? Well, the first thing we do
is sponsor community events.

We have a happy hour after
this seminar every Friday. So whenever you come to this
seminar or you don't come,

come to the happy hour afterward
to interact with each other. Everybody's friendly. That's actually a nice thing
about the worldwide robotics

community, is that what
I found and I met people from a lot of different
places, robotics is a pretty friendly
community, which is great

if you're going to have
a career in something, it's nice to be with people
that you like to be around. So we're building that community
and creating opportunities
to come together. This is one view of the center.

There's a lot of space. It's the basement of
Packard, and you're welcome to walk through anytime.

There's a bunch of
different rooms there. And we've got a dance studio.

The dance studio
is there to help us understand how people move. And we have motion capture
in there so we can track it.

And in the demonstration
that's going on, we're understanding human
motion and rerendering robots

doing the same motion
at the same time. There's a human robot
interaction studio, which is a stage that we can
create situations for people

to interact with robots. The current setup, it's
designed to make you feel like you're underwater.

And you walk through it and you
experience videos of OceanOne, and you actually get to be
next to OceanOne the robot.

We have haptic control
devices in the center. We've got a domestic suite that
looks like a home a little bit.

It's easy to do. You take a room and you go to
the IKEA website and you say, here's my room. And then you order whatever
they tell you to order and boom,

you have a domestic suite. But we set it up and
we've got robots in there that are doing some work
autonomously, tidying up
the floor, making the bed. There's some feeding robot.

There's some toddler bots that
are in there at the moment. We've got a kitchen and there's
this white robot is actually

from Germany, from Karlsruhe. And that robot,
a copy of that is

going to be coming back
to be here permanently. So we have a humanoid
robot in the center.

But it's not about
a specific robot. As a center, we're trying
to create a set of resources

that you all can
use to do research to learn about robotics.

Medical bay, from this picture
you probably can't see much, but to tell you
it's very crowded. There's five different
projects going on in there.

We have a da Vinci
surgical robot. We've got the magnetic spinner
robots that I showed you.

We've got a remote
ultrasound project, a project with soft robotic
grippers to bathe people.

And that's just
the current ones. There's a bunch of seed projects
that we are getting going with.

In field robotics, there's
a really cool robot that I called the reachbot
out of Marks Lab that

has these arms
that are this small and can reach out 10
feet in any direction

and then have a
gripper on the end. And the core
technology behind it is actually this thing that's a
tape measure that was designed,

and you can buy it. They sell them to
people who own boats. You basically make a long stick
out of a very small package,

and then you can use
it to grab the dock or grab something overboard. But if you put it on
a motor, suddenly you

have a linear actuator
that can go much longer than its form, which
makes it for a very interesting piece of a robot.

There's drones,
space to fly drones.

And so a manufacturing
logistic bay. And someday, for some
who watches this video, someday we will have a pool.

Although it turns out to be very
difficult to actually get it built for some reason.

We've also got other
robots in the area. Mark mentioned my
last company, this

is a relay robot, which
is basically the simplest robot you can imagine.

It's around diff-drive robot. And if you're a roboticist
you're like, that's boring. I spent 10 years getting
it out into the world

to actually be used. I mean, getting it built was
five months, the first version. But getting it actually to where
hospitals will adopt it, where

they say, how reliable is it? And you want to get to how
many nines of reliability? Because of course, what
its doing in hospitals,

it's carrying blood samples
or tissue samples to the lab.

So if you come in and get
a biopsy and then you say, OK, we took your biopsy.

We put the samples in the lab
and we sent it to the lab. And if the robot fails, they're
going to call you back and say,

we need to do another biopsy. This is not a good outcome. So you have to have high
reliability in that application.

We started in hotels. It was a little bit lower bar. You can send ice cream. If the ice cream melts you
can just send another one.
So a lot of interesting robots. So I talked about impact. And I want to come back to that.

And let me think about this
in a couple of different ways. If you talk about impact
commercially, what you mean is,

I did something that
I had some capital and I came up with a product
that people want to buy.

And people buy my service and I
make money on each transaction. That's an important part
of that startup thing

that a lot of
companies don't get. But it's important. And then you're
actually increasing

the amount of capital. So over time you're
increasing capital. That's the goal of a company. In academia it's a
little bit different.

What are we trying to do? We're trying to get people to
study and build on our results.

We're trying to publish papers. We're trying to write patents. We're trying to build things,
build new capabilities,

and demonstrate
them as a community so that we can build each other. Build on each other's work.

And the goal is
to grow knowledge. That's what academics or
universities are set up to do.

So those are
different but similar. And I'll come back
to Willow Garage.

So Willow Garage was
this, as I say, halfway house for wayward researchers
on their way to startups.

It's one way we
thought about it. And out of Willow Garage
came two things primarily,

the PR2 robot and ROS. And one of the
things, Willow Garage

got a ton of press and
interest over time. It turns out if
you're in robotics,

it's easy to get press. You know why? Because you can take
pictures of robots. It's really hard to take
pictures of enterprise software.

You just take a picture
of a person at a computer. But robots, you can take
pictures, you can take videos. And so you get free media.

It's a great thing. For some value of great. But what actually survives
from Willow Garage

is not the hardware. It's the software
that you can't see. But ROS has a much, much
bigger impact than PR2 did.

And even when we first
started, before we released the first version of ROS, before
we released any hardware robot,

because we were a
very open place, we found there were
people downloading parts of the software that
we were building, taking it

apart and using it. I visited a university
at Sherbrooke in Canada

and they said yeah, we're
already using your stuff. I'm like, we haven't
released anything. How can that be? Well, we were open.

We were very open. We had meetings internally. We saved the notes
on an open wiki. And apparently people
were following us.

Can I ask a question? Because as a hardware guy, I
get hit with this all the time.

That, oh, well, it just
wasn't the hardware. It's hard to assimilate
into our company.

It's just hard to scale,
doesn't really have the impact. The thing is, though, that
in order to develop ROS,

you needed some hardware
there that you were working with in order to do it. And this particular
hardware brought

to light a bunch of
human interaction issues that turned out to be
really important for ROS, that you probably wouldn't
have thought about if you

were doing with all
the tiny robots that work in manufacturing.

So yes, ROS per se
has the bigger impact.

But it's a little bit like
saying that, like I'm a sculptor

and my sculpture has the
big impact and the chisel that I'm working with did
not have a big impact.

Well, no. So I don't mean to say
that hardware is not-- let me be clear.

In this case, for Willow
Garage, 10 years later, ROS had a bigger impact
because it touched more people.

Hardware can have a huge impact. IPhone is having massive
impact on the world.

And smartphones generally,
everybody carries one. There's billions of copies. Hardware works when
there's lots of copies.

And even prototype hardware is
valuable in that it gets you to the next prototype.

One of the interesting things
that happened at Willow Garage was we had a meeting
one day and I

was sitting at the
head of the table watching the leadership team
of Willow go back and forth.

And there was this
big argument going on. And I was listening to
it trying to figure out, what were they
arguing about and why?

And it finally had
this uh-huh moment. Because the argument broke down
around hardware versus software.

And the software
people were arguing

about how we do things,
how we get things done. And I realized that as a
computer scientist when

I was an undergrad, my first
software engineering class,

there was the stuff I didn't
understand in the first chapter. I just glossed over
it, but I remember it.

It was, there are
these waterfall models and they're wrong. And there are
these loopy models,
which we might call agile now. And that's what we should do. And this was in the '80s.

So a long time ago we were
talking about waterfall bad, agile good. And in this meeting I realized
that the hardware people

hadn't gotten the memo, that
they're still doing waterfall. But there's a good
reason for this. I mean, yes, we want
to be more agile.

Yes, we have 3D printers. Yes, we can make prototypes
as fast as we can. But in the end of the day if
you're going to make a product,

the result of the
hardware is going to be a design which you're
going to send to a manufacturer.

And they're going to
make it and they're going to send you back copies. And you have to actually pay
for every single copy you get.

And software, you can
put it out and then you could change
it over the air.

And that's a big,
big difference.  The other thing difference
between hardware and software

that's really important
and to think about as roboticists is the software
people mostly, maybe AI

is changing this, but
mostly can't cause harm. Whatever I could do in my
code, the worst I can do

is brick my computer. But hardware people
can kill people.

I mean, you can chop
off fingers and things. You've got motors.

You're creating
force on the world. You can electrocute people. So hardware people
learn safety in a way

that software people
don't automatically as part of the curriculum. And that's a really
important piece as well. And again, a reason why we need
to work together in robotics.

I think I've digressed. But let me come
back to the story. So ROS and PR2 at Willow Garage,
we were starting this company.

It was, I say, a
strange company. It was funded and then we grew
to catch up to the funding.

So I was like, here's your
$20 million a year, go. It's a great job if you
can get it by the way.

I was the CEO there. And let me hire a great team
under me and try to make impact.

What we came up
with after a while, we didn't originally start
with PR2 and ROS as a vision.

We started with the vague
idea of autonomous technology. We actually had a self-driving
car project that it was painful,

but we canceled
it after we didn't get to the finals of the
DARPA Urban Challenge in 2007.

But when we finally
settled on this, we said, OK, what
are our milestones?

And these were the four
milestones that we came up with. Navigate 2 pi kilometers
indoors autonomously.
Why 2 pi? We had to pick a number. We picked that. It seemed like a good number.

Why just navigate, why
not any manipulation? Because the arms
weren't done yet.

We were building the
robot in two parts. We had arms that came out
of a design from Stanford. They were supposed to
be human safe arms.

They were
gravity-counterbalanced. So you could have small
motors in the shoulder so they could be safe
and still manipulate things, is one of the cool
things about that robot.

But we didn't have
the arms done yet. They were taking a while, so we
just built the base and tried, let's get the basic
navigation stack working.

And at this time navigation
was a solved problem. And we spent a year and a half
or whatever getting it to work.

So solved problem for
some value of solved. Now, second milestone was
also performance milestone.

Navigate a marathon. So this time you're going to
have to stop and charge along the way. And so we had to
program the robot

to be able to plug itself in. And we thought that
it would be cool to--

we were doing this to try
to demonstrate the arm. So don't build a charging dock. That's the obvious solution now.

But we get to modify
the plug because that's part of the robot. So we made it nice and square so
the parallel jaw grippers could

hold it and put a ARTag on it
because that makes it easier to know exactly where it is. You still have to
see the wall socket.

And we didn't let them put
markers on the wall socket. And we learned, this is
pre-2012, so pre-AI machine

or big data, and
so we're learning using whatever techniques
we had at the time to recognize that
one plug really well.

And we were able to
plug-in in that one plug. We didn't get to
the solution of, we want to be able to go
into any arbitrary room.

Or the third one
was open the doors. And we did get so we
could open the doors. So here you have a robot

real-world problems. And the real-world
problem in this case is here I've got a

an elevator degree of freedom. So you get up to the counter
or get down and could even

touch the floor,
but it can't really see where it's

We couldn't pick things

In order to show that you could

This is not let's say, the
